intro: Senecio pampeanus f. serratus, commonly known as the serrated pampas groundsel, is a perennial herb native to the Pampas region of Argentina. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and fibrous root system. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy, linear leaves that have serrated margins, giving it its specific epithet. Its flowering period occurs during the spring and early summer, producing yellow flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The species is well adapted to the dry, open grasslands of its native habitat, showing resilience to drought and grazing.
